question.title: Efficient regex to split ingredient measures and units

node.contents: `x g to y g` seems quite strange imho, especially when you're also using `x - y g`. Is that really the desired output?

elements.contents: text = text.replaceAll( "([0-9])-([0-9])", "$1 to $2" ); text = text.replaceAll( "([^0-9])/([0-9])", "$1 / $2" ); return text.replaceAll( "([0-9])([^0-9 /])", "$1 $2" );

node.contents: If this method is used a lot you would probably gain more by pre-compiling all the patterns and use the compiled patterns here instead.

astNode.text: If this method is used a lot you would probably gain more by pre-compiling all the patterns and use the compiled patterns here instead.

node.contents: Here's a one-liner using nothing but look-arounds to insert a space:

astNode.text: Here's a one-liner using nothing but look-arounds to insert a space:

node.contents: This works for all your cases. Here's a some testing code:

astNode.text: This works for all your cases. Here's a some testing code:

elements.contents: public static void main(String[] args) { String[] inputs = { "180-200g/6-7oz flour", "3-5g sugar", "6g to 7g sugar", "2 1/2 tbsp flour", "3/4 cup flour" }; String[] outputs = { "180 - 200 g / 6 - 7 oz flour", "3 - 5 g sugar", "6 g to 7 g sugar", "2 1/2 tbsp flour", "3/4 cup flour" }; int i = 0; for (String input : inputs) { String output = input.replaceAll("(?=-)|(?<=-)|(?<=[^\\d ])(?=/)|(?<=\\d/?)(?=[^\\d /])|(?<=\\D/)(?=\\d)", " "); if (!output.equals(outputs[i++])) { System.out.println("Failed with input: " + input); System.out.println("Expected: " + outputs[i - 1]); System.out.println(" Actual: " + output); } } }

units.rawText: public static void main(String[] args) { String[] inputs = { "180-200g/6-7oz flour", "3-5g sugar", "6g to 7g sugar", "2 1/2 tbsp flour", "3/4 cup flour"}; String[] outputs = { "180 - 200 g / 6 - 7 oz flour", "3 - 5 g sugar", "6 g to 7 g sugar", "2 1/2 tbsp flour", "3/4 cup flour"}; int i = 0; for (String input : inputs) { String output = input.replaceAll("(?=-)|(?<=-)|(?<=[^\\d ])(?=/)|(?<=\\d/?)(?=[^\\d /])|(?<=\\D/)(?=\\d)", " "); if (!output.equals(outputs[i++])) { System.out.println("Failed with input: "+ input); System.out.println("Expected: "+ outputs[i - 1]); System.out.println(" Actual: "+ output); } } }

node.contents: This appears to (incorrectly) split the `3/4` into `3 / 4`.

node.contents: @Dave: You're right, I forgot about that. Add a `.replaceAll( "\\s+/\\s+", "/")` after the line that handles `\b`.

astNode.text: @Dave: You're right, I forgot about that. Add a `.replaceAll( "\\s+/\\s+", "/")` after the line that handles `\b`.

node.contents: Four calls to `replaceAll` will be less efficient than three, no?

astNode.text: Four calls to `replaceAll` will be less efficient than three, no?

node.contents: @Dave Doing X four times will always be slower than doing X three times. Anyway, about what kind of efficiency are we talking about here? Will it *really* affect your program's performance?
